publications: [{"title":"Risk‑adjusted Returns from Statistical Arbitrage Opportunities in Indian Stock Futures Market","subtitle":"Springer Nature","date":"July 16, 2020","description":"Statistical arbitrage is a trading strategy that employs time series methods to identify relative mispricing between securities based on the expected values of these assets. The Pairs Trading, one of the techniques of statistical arbitrage, is a market neutral trading strategy. The daily future prices of stocks traded and listed on NSE are used on rolling basis to compute the performance based on the selection of pairs through minimizing the sum of squared deviation (distance method) and the selection based on cointegration tests (cointegration method) for identifying stocks suited for pairs trading strategies. To examine the risk of pairs trading and the drivers of returns, the portfolio returns are risk-adjusted using Fama and French three factor asset pricing model."},{"title":"Risk Measurement: An Introduction to Value-at-Risk (VaR)","subtitle":"National Press Associates","date":"February 15, 2020","description":"Value at risk (VaR) has been called the \"new science of risk management\", which calculates the maximum loss expected (or worst case scenario) on an investment, over a given time period and given a specified degree of confidence. We explain the concept of VaR, and then describe three methods for computing it."}]
